item.description: Learn how threat exposure management (TEM) and CTEM work, how to implement them, and align these strategies with cybersecurity frameworks and tools.

item.title: Digital Fraud Costs Companies Worldwide 7.7% of Annual Revenue
item.description: According to TransUnion, digital fraud has cost companies $534bn in losses globally with US business hit hardest

item.title: Step Into the Password Graveyard… If You Dare (and Join the Live Session)
item.description: Every year, weak passwords lead to millions in losses — and many of those breaches could have been stopped. Attackers don’t need advanced tools; they just need one careless login. For IT teams, that means endless resets, compliance struggles, and sleepless nights worrying about the next credential leak. This Halloween, The Hacker News and Specops Software invite you to a live webinar: “
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Severe Figma MCP Vulnerability Lets Hackers Execute Code Remotely — Patch Now
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a now-patched vulnerability in the popular figma-developer-mcp Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that could allow attackers to achieve code execution. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-53967 (CVSS score: 7.5), is a command injection bug stemming from the unsanitized use of user input, opening the door to a scenario where an attacker can
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cyber-Attack Contributes to Huge Sales Drop at JLR
item.description: Jaguar Land Rover has reported a 25% drop in volume sales in the three months up to September 30, largely due to the impact of the ongoing cyber incident

item.title: Bybit Theft Drives Record-Breaking $2bn Haul for North Korea
item.description: North Korean hackers have stolen over $2bn in cryptocurrency already this year, says Elliptic

item.title: No Time to Waste: Embedding AI to Cut Noise and Reduce Risk
item.description: Artificial intelligence is reshaping cybersecurity on both sides of the battlefield. Cybercriminals are using AI-powered tools to accelerate and automate attacks at a scale defenders have never faced before. Security teams are overwhelmed by an explosion of vulnerability data, tool outputs, and alerts, all while operating with finite human resources. The irony is that while AI has become a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: How to Prevent Subdomain Takeovers | UpGuard
item.description: Learn how subdomain takeovers happen, how to prevent them, and what steps to take if your subdomain is compromised. Includes real-world examples and tools.

item.title: Met Police Arrest Two Teens in Connection with Kido Attack
item.description: Two 17-year-olds have been arrested following a cyber-attack on the Kido nursery group

item.title: OpenAI Disrupts Russian, North Korean, and Chinese Hackers Misusing ChatGPT for Cyberattacks
item.description: OpenAI on Tuesday said it disrupted three activity clusters for misusing its ChatGPT artificial intelligence (AI) tool to facilitate malware development. This includes a Russian‑language threat actor, who is said to have used the chatbot to help develop and refine a remote access trojan (RAT), a credential stealer with an aim to evade detection. The operator also used several ChatGPT accounts to
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cyberattack Leads to Beer Shortage as Asahi Recovers
item.description: A ransomware last week left the Asahi brewery in Japan struggling to take orders and deliver its products domestically, as manufacturers become a favored target.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.description: Learn about digital risk protection, how to implement it with a step-by-step framework, and how to safeguard your organization from modern digital threats.

item.description: Protect your organization from data leaks with UpGuard’s best practices and tools. Learn how to prevent sensitive information from being exposed or stolen.

item.title: ShinyHunters Wage Broad Corporate Extortion Spree
item.description: A cybercriminal group that used voice phishing attacks to siphon more than a billion records from Salesforce customers earlier this year has launched a website that threatens to publish data stolen from dozens of Fortune 500 firms if they refuse to pay a ransom. The group also claimed responsibility for a recent breach involving Discord user data, and for stealing terabytes of sensitive files from thousands of customers of the enterprise software maker Red Hat.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: Attackers Season Spam With a Touch of 'Salt'
item.description: Researchers report an increase in the use of hidden content in spam and malicious email to confuse filters and other security mechanisms.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Security Concerns Shadow Vibe Coding Adoption
item.description: In a recent poll, readers shared how they're using vibe coding in AppDev (if they are at all). While some found success, others found the risks too great.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Qilin Ransomware Gang Claims Asahi Cyber-Attack
item.description: The Qilin group claims to have stolen sensitive personal and proprietary data from the Brewer

item.title: BatShadow Group Uses New Go-Based 'Vampire Bot' Malware to Hunt Job Seekers
item.description: A Vietnamese threat actor named BatShadow has been attributed to a new campaign that leverages social engineering tactics to deceive job seekers and digital marketing professionals to deliver a previously undocumented malware called Vampire Bot. "The attackers pose as recruiters, distributing malicious files disguised as job descriptions and corporate documents," Aryaka Threat Research Labs
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Medusa Ransomware Actors Exploit Critical Fortra GoAnywhere Flaw
item.description: Researchers say exploitation of CVE-2025-10035 requires a private key, and it's unclear how Storm-1175 threat actors pulled this off.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Google's New AI Doesn't Just Find Vulnerabilities — It Rewrites Code to Patch Them
item.description: Google's DeepMind division on Monday announced an artificial intelligence (AI)-powered agent called CodeMender that automatically detects, patches, and rewrites vulnerable code to prevent future exploits. The efforts add to the company's ongoing efforts to improve AI-powered vulnerability discovery, such as Big Sleep and OSS-Fuzz. DeepMind said the AI agent is designed to be both reactive and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: A critical Redis flaw, dubbed “RediShell,” has exposed 60,000 unprotected servers to exploitation

item.title: New Research: AI Is Already the #1 Data Exfiltration Channel in the Enterprise
item.description: For years, security leaders have treated artificial intelligence as an “emerging” technology, something to keep an eye on but not yet mission-critical. A new Enterprise AI and SaaS Data Security Report by AI &amp; Browser Security company LayerX proves just how outdated that mindset has become. Far from a future concern, AI is already the single largest uncontrolled channel for corporate data
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: XWorm 6.0 Returns with 35+ Plugins and Enhanced Data Theft Capabilities
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have charted the evolution of XWorm malware, turning it into a versatile tool for supporting a wide range of malicious actions on compromised hosts. "XWorm's modular design is built around a core client and an array of specialized components known as plugins," Trellix researchers Niranjan Hegde and Sijo Jacob said in an analysis published last week. "These plugins are
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Patch Now: 'RediShell' Threatens Cloud Via Redis RCE
item.description: A 13-year-old flaw with a CVSS score of 10 in the popular data storage service allows for full host takeover, and more than 300k instances are currently exposed.

item.title: 13-Year-Old Redis Flaw Exposed: CVSS 10.0 Vulnerability Lets Attackers Run Code Remotely
item.description: Redis has disclosed details of a maximum-severity security flaw in its in-memory database software that could result in remote code execution under certain circumstances. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-49844 (aka RediShell), has been assigned a CVSS score of 10.0. "An authenticated user may use a specially crafted Lua script to manipulate the garbage collector, trigger a use-after-free,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Links Storm-1175 to GoAnywhere Exploit Deploying Medusa Ransomware
item.description: Microsoft on Monday attributed a threat actor it tracks as Storm-1175 to the exploitation of a critical security flaw in Fortra GoAnywhere software to facilitate the deployment of Medusa ransomware. item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: A Chinese company named the Beijing Institute of Electronics Technology and Application (BIETA) has been assessed to be likely led by the Ministry of State Security (MSS). item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Oracle 0-Day, BitLocker Bypass, VMScape, WhatsApp Worm & More
item.description: The cyber world never hits pause, and staying alert matters more than ever. Every week brings new tricks, smarter attacks, and fresh lessons from the field. This recap cuts through the noise to share what really matters—key trends, warning signs, and stories shaping today’s security landscape. Whether you’re defending systems or just keeping up, these highlights help you spot what’s coming
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 5 Critical Questions For Adopting an AI Security Solution
item.description: In the era of rapidly advancing artificial intelligence (AI) and cloud technologies, organizations are increasingly implementing security measures to protect sensitive data and ensure regulatory compliance. Among these measures, AI-SPM (AI Security Posture Management) solutions have gained traction to secure AI pipelines, sensitive data assets, and the overall AI ecosystem. These solutions help
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Oracle Rushes Patch for CVE-2025-61882 After Cl0p Exploited It in Data Theft Attacks
item.description: Oracle has released an emergency update to address a critical security flaw in its E-Business Suite software that it said has been exploited in the recent wave of Cl0p data theft attacks. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-61882 (CVSS score: 9.8), concerns an unspecified bug that could allow an unauthenticated attacker with network access via HTTP to compromise and take control of the Oracle
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Chinese Cybercrime Group Runs Global SEO Fraud Ring Using Compromised IIS Servers
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have shed light on a Chinese-speaking cybercrime group codenamed UAT-8099 that has been attributed to search engine optimization (SEO) fraud and theft of high-value credentials, configuration files, and certificate data.&nbsp; The attacks are designed to target Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) servers, with most of the infections reported in India, Thailand
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI in the 2026 Midterm Elections
item.description: <p>We are nearly one year out from the 2026 midterm elections, and it&#8217;s far too early to predict the outcomes. But it&#8217;s a safe bet that artificial intelligence technologies will once again be a major storyline.</p> <p>The widespread fear that AI would be used to manipulate the 2024 U.S. election seems rather quaint in a year where the president posts <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cdrg8zkz8d0o">AI-generated images</a> of himself as the pope on official White House accounts. But AI is a lot more than an information manipulator. It&#8217;s also emerging as a <a href="https://www.brookings.edu/articles/trumps-executive-orders-politicize-ai/">politicized</a> issue. Political first-movers are adopting the technology, and that&#8217;s opening a ...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Self-Propagating Malware Hits WhatsApp Users in Brazil
item.description: The enterprise-focused Water Saci campaign spreads Sorvepotel, which can steal credentials and monitor browser activity to defraud financial institutions in the region.

item.title: Zimbra Zero-Day Exploited to Target Brazilian Military via Malicious ICS Files
item.description: A now patched security vulnerability in Zimbra Collaboration was exploited as a zero-day earlier this year in cyber attacks targeting the Brazilian military. item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new attack called CometJacking targeting Perplexity's agentic AI browser Comet by embedding malicious prompts within a seemingly innocuous link to siphon sensitive data, including from connected services, like email and calendar. The sneaky prompt injection attack plays out in the form of a malicious link that, when clicked, triggers the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Scanning Activity on Palo Alto Networks Portals Jump 500% in One Day
item.description: Threat intelligence firm GreyNoise disclosed on Friday that it has observed a massive spike in scanning activity targeting Palo Alto Networks login portals. The company said it observed a nearly 500% increase in IP addresses scanning Palo Alto Networks login portals on October 3, 2025, the highest level recorded in the last three months. It described the traffic as targeted and structured, and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

That's according to findings from Infoblox, which found the threat actor to maintain control of domains hosting the first stage of the stealer, a backdoor called StarFish. The DNS threat intelligence firm said it has been tracking Detour Dog since August 2023, when
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Warn of Self-Spreading WhatsApp Malware Named SORVEPOTEL
item.description: Brazilian users have emerged as the target of a new self-propagating malware dubbed SORVEPOTEL that spreads via the popular messaging app WhatsApp. The campaign, codenamed Water Saci by Trend Micro, weaponizes the trust with the platform to extend its reach across Windows systems, adding the attack is "engineered for speed and propagation" rather than data theft or ransomware. "SORVEPOTEL has
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: Passwork is positioned as an on-premises unified platform for both password and secrets management, aiming to address the increasing complexity of credential storage and sharing in modern organizations. item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: Google Mandiant and Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) have disclosed that they are tracking a new cluster of activity possibly linked to a financially motivated threat actor known as Cl0p. item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: How to Close Threat Detection Gaps: Your SOC's Action Plan
item.description: Running a SOC often feels like drowning in alerts. Every morning, dashboards light up with thousands of signals; some urgent, many irrelevant. The job is to find the real threats fast enough to keep cases from piling up, prevent analyst burnout, and maintain client or leadership confidence. The toughest challenges, however, aren’t the alerts that can be dismissed quickly, but the ones that hide
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Warning: Beware of Android Spyware Disguised as Signal Encryption Plugin and ToTok Pro
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered two Android spyware campaigns dubbed ProSpy and ToSpy that impersonate apps like Signal and ToTok to target users in the United Arab Emirates (U.A.E.). Slovak cybersecurity company ESET said the malicious apps are distributed via fake websites and social engineering to trick unsuspecting users into downloading them. Once installed, both the spyware
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Android Spyware in the UAE Masquerades as ... Spyware
item.description: In a clever, messed-up twist on brand impersonation, attackers are passing off their spyware as a notorious UAE government surveillance app.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Google Sheds Light on ShinyHunters' Salesforce Tactics
item.description: Mandiant provided proactive defenses against UNC6040's social engineering attacks that have led to several Salesforce breaches.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Shutdown Threatens US Intel Sharing, Cyber Defense
item.description: Lapse of critical information sharing and mass furloughs at CISA are just some of the concerns.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: New WireTap Attack Extracts Intel SGX ECDSA Key via DDR4 Memory-Bus Interposer
item.description: In yet another piece of research, academics from Georgia Institute of Technology and Purdue University have demonstrated that the security guarantees offered by Intel's Software Guard eXtensions (SGX) can be bypassed on DDR4 systems to passively decrypt sensitive data. SGX is designed as a hardware feature in Intel server processors that allows applications to be run in a Trusted Execution
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: A $50 'Battering RAM' Can Bust Confidential Computing
item.description: Researchers have demonstrated an attack that can break through modern Intel and AMD processor technologies that protect encrypted data stored in memory.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: The AI Exchange: Innovators in Payment Security Featuring Elavon Inc.
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: Undead Operating Systems Haunt Enterprise Security Networks
item.description: Windows 10 reaches end-of-life on Oct. 14, which will triple the number of vulnerable enterprise systems and create a massive attack surface for cybercriminals.
item.dc:creator: Fahmida Y. Rashid

item.title: Key Vendor Risk Assessment Criteria and How to Apply Them | UpGuard
item.description: Learn how to apply vendor risk assessment criteria effectively. Use automation, scoring tools, and checklists to reduce third-party risk.
